set.!doc: Set the reverb settings. Similar to .process(), but without assigning a new input.

amp.!type: fn(volume: number, rampTime?: number, timeFromNow?: number)
amp.!doc: Set the output level of the delay effect.

connect.!doc: Send output to a p5.sound or web audio object

p5.Convolver.!type: fn(path: string, callback?: fn(), errorCallback?: fn()) -> +p5.sound.p5.Convolver
p5.Convolver.!doc:
p5.Convolver extends p5.Reverb. It can emulate the sound of real physical spaces through a process called convolution.

Convolution multiplies any audio input by an "impulse response" to simulate the dispersion of sound over time. The impulse response is generated from an audio file that you provide. One way to generate an impulse response is to pop a balloon in a reverberant space and record the echo. Convolution can also be used to experiment with sound.

Use the method createConvolution(path) to instantiate a p5.Convolver with a path to your impulse response audio file.

convolverNode.!doc: Internally, the p5.Convolver uses the a Web Audio Convolver Node.

createConvolver.!type: fn(path: string, callback?: fn(), errorCallback?: fn()) -> +p5.sound.p5.Convolver
createConvolver.!doc: Create a p5.Convolver. Accepts a path to a soundfile that will be used to generate an impulse response.

process.!doc: Connect a source to the reverb, and assign reverb parameters.

impulses.!doc: If you load multiple impulse files using the .addImpulse method, they will be stored as Objects in this Array. Toggle between them with the toggleImpulse(id) method.

addImpulse.!type: fn(path: string, callback: fn(), errorCallback: fn())
addImpulse.!doc: Load and assign a new Impulse Response to the p5.Convolver. The impulse is added to the .impulses array. Previous impulses can be accessed with the .toggleImpulse(id) method.

resetImpulse.!type: fn(path: string, callback: fn(), errorCallback: fn())
resetImpulse.!doc: Similar to .addImpulse, except that the .impulses Array is reset to save memory. A new .impulses array is created with this impulse as the only item.

toggleImpulse.!doc:
If you have used .addImpulse() to add multiple impulses to a p5.Convolver, then you can use this method to toggle between the items in the .impulses Array. Accepts a parameter to identify which impulse you wish to use, identified either by its original filename (String) or by its position in the .impulses Array (Number).
You can access the objects in the .impulses Array directly. Each Object has two attributes: an .audioBuffer (type: Web Audio AudioBuffer) and a .name, a String that corresponds with the original filename.

undefined.!doc: Set the global tempo, in beats per minute, for all p5.Parts. This method will impact all active p5.Parts.

p5.Phrase.!type: fn(name: string, callback: fn(), sequence: Array) -> +p5.sound.p5.Phrase
p5.Phrase.!doc:
A phrase is a pattern of musical events over time, i.e. a series of notes and rests.

Phrases must be added to a p5.Part for playback, and each part can play multiple phrases at the same time. For example, one Phrase might be a kick drum, another could be a snare, and another could be the bassline.

The first parameter is a name so that the phrase can be modified or deleted later. The callback is a a function that this phrase will call at every stepâ€”for example it might be called playNote(value){}. The array determines which value is passed into the callback at each step of the phrase. It can be numbers, an object with multiple numbers, or a zero (0) indicates a rest so the callback won't be called).

sequence.!doc: Array of values to pass into the callback at each step of the phrase. Depending on the callback function's requirements, these values may be numbers, strings, or an object with multiple parameters. Zero (0) indicates a rest.

p5.Part.!doc:
A p5.Part plays back one or more p5.Phrases. Instantiate a part with steps and tatums. By default, each step represents 1/16th note.

See p5.Phrase for more about musical timing.

setBPM.!doc: Set the tempo of this part, in Beats Per Minute.

getBPM.!doc: Returns the Beats Per Minute of this currently part.

start.!doc: Start playback of this part. It will play through all of its phrases at a speed determined by setBPM.

loop.!doc: Loop playback of this part. It will begin looping through all of its phrases at a speed determined by setBPM.

stop.!doc: Stop the part and cue it to step 0.

pause.!doc: Pause the part. Playback will resume from the current step.

removePhrase.!doc: Remove a phrase from this part, based on the name it was given when it was created.

getPhrase.!doc: Get a phrase from this part, based on the name it was given when it was created. Now you can modify its array.

replaceSequence.!doc: Get a phrase from this part, based on the name it was given when it was created. Now you can modify its array.

onStep.!doc: Fire a callback function at every step.

p5.Score.!doc: A Score consists of a series of Parts. The parts will be played back in order. For example, you could have an A part, a B part, and a C part, and play them back in this order new p5.Score(a, a, b, a, c)

noLoop.!doc: Stop looping playback of the score. If it is currently playing, this will go into effect after the current round of playback completes.

undefined.!doc: Set the tempo for all parts in the score

p5.SoundRecorder.!doc:
Record sounds for playback and/or to save as a .wav file. The p5.SoundRecorder records all sound output from your sketch, or can be assigned a specific source with setInput().

The record() method accepts a p5.SoundFile as a parameter. When playback is stopped (either after the given amount of time, or with the stop() method), the p5.SoundRecorder will send its recording to that p5.SoundFile for playback.

setInput.!doc: Connect a specific device to the p5.SoundRecorder. If no parameter is given, p5.SoundRecorer will record all audible p5.sound from your sketch.

record.!type: fn(soundFile: p5.sound.p5.SoundFile, duration?: number, callback?: fn())
record.!doc: Start recording. To access the recording, provide a p5.SoundFile as the first parameter. The p5.SoundRecorder will send its recording to that p5.SoundFile for playback once recording is complete. Optional parameters include duration (in seconds) of the recording, and a callback function that will be called once the complete recording has been transfered to the p5.SoundFile.

stop.!doc: Stop the recording. Once the recording is stopped, the results will be sent to the p5.SoundFile that was given on .record(), and if a callback function was provided on record, that function will be called.

saveSound.!doc: Save a p5.SoundFile as a .wav audio file.

p5.PeakDetect.!type: fn(freq1?: number, freq2?: number, threshold?: number, framesPerPeak?: number) -> +p5.sound.p5.PeakDetect
p5.PeakDetect.!doc:
PeakDetect works in conjunction with p5.FFT to look for onsets in some or all of the frequency spectrum.

To use p5.PeakDetect, call update in the draw loop and pass in a p5.FFT object.

You can listen for a specific part of the frequency spectrum by setting the range between freq1 and freq2.

threshold is the threshold for detecting a peak, scaled between 0 and 1. It is logarithmic, so 0.1 is half as loud as 1.0.

The update method is meant to be run in the draw loop, and frames determines how many loops must pass before another peak can be detected. For example, if the frameRate() = 60, you could detect the beat of a 120 beat-per-minute song with this equation: framesPerPeak = 60 / (estimatedBPM / 60 );

Based on example contribtued by @b2renger, and a simple beat detection explanation by a href="http://www.airtightinteractive.com/2013/10/making-audio-reactive-visuals/" target="_blank"Felix Turner.

isDetected.!doc: isDetected is set to true when a peak is detected.

update.!doc:
The update method is run in the draw loop.

Accepts an FFT object. You must call .analyze() on the FFT object prior to updating the peakDetect because it relies on a completed FFT analysis.

onPeak.!doc: onPeak accepts two arguments: a function to call when a peak is detected. The value of the peak, between 0.0 and 1.0, is passed to the callback.

p5.Gain.!doc: A gain node is usefull to set the relative volume of sound. It's typically used to build mixers.

setInput.!doc: Connect a source to the gain node.

connect.!doc: Send output to a p5.sound or web audio object

amp.!type: fn(volume: number, rampTime?: number, timeFromNow?: number)
amp.!doc: Set the output level of the gain node.

p5.Distortion.!doc: A Distortion effect created with a Waveshaper Node, with an approach adapted from Kevin Ennis

WaveShaperNode.!doc: The p5.Distortion is built with a Web Audio WaveShaper Node.

setType.!doc: Set the amount and oversample of the waveshaper distortion.

undefined.!doc: Return the oversampling.

connect.!doc: Send output to a p5.sound or web audio object
